heading.title: PART 2 THE LOCAL COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 7–28]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 2 THE LOCAL COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 7–28]

leg:heading.title: THE LOCAL COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 7–28]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7] s 7 Constitution of the Court (cf LCA, sections 6, 8A and 8B)

leg:heading.title: Constitution of the Court (cf LCA, sections 6 , 8A and 8B )

p.text: There is constituted by this Act a court of record to be known as the Local Court of New South Wales.
There is to be a seal of the Court and any document that is required by or under this Act or any other Act or law to be sealed or stamped with the seal of the Court is to be so sealed or stamped.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7.5] LCA 2007 s 7(1): court of record

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 7.

Under this section, the Local Court is constituted a court of record by statute, as were, for the purposes of the exercise of civil jurisdiction, Courts of Petty Sessions exercising jurisdiction under the Small Debts Recovery Act 1912 ( s 5 ) and the Small Debts Recovery Act 1899 (s 5). A court of record is a court "whose acts and judicial proceedings are enrolled for a perpetual memory and testimony; whose rolls are the records of the court": HN Mozley, Mozley & Whiteley's law dictionary, 10th ed, Butterworths, London, 1988. A court of record meant originally one whose acts and proceedings were enrolled in parchment. At about the beginning of the 17th century the common law courts developed the doctrine that only a court of record could fine or imprison, by statute or otherwise, for contempt of itself or for other substantive offences. Conversely, there developed the doctrine that a court which could fine and imprison was a court of record. In the case of the civil courts, it was said that courts of record were those which had the power to hear and determine actions in which the debt, damages or value of the property claimed was £2 or over: see Halsbury's Laws of England, vol 10, 4th ed, at [308] fn 3. Since the Justices Legislation Repeal and Amendment Act 2001 took effect on 1 July 2003, Local Courts generally were expressed to be courts of record per medium of LCA 1982 s 8A . This status is preserved by LCA 2007 s 7 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7.10] Local Court's status as an inferior court of record

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 7.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 75A(3).

heading.title: Local Court's status as an inferior court of record

p.text: The Local Court is an inferior court and is bound to follow the decisions of superior courts, and if it is clear what the ratio decidendi is which led to that decision, then the ratio decidendi is also binding: Great Western Railway Co v Owners of SS Mostyn [1928] AC 57 at 73; [1927] All ER Rep 113 per Viscount Dunedin; see also F Hoffmann-La-Roche & Co AG v Secretary of State for Trade and Industry [1975] AC 295 at 365; [1974] 2 All ER 1128 per Lord Diplock; Burwood Council v PD Mayoh Pty Ltd (1997) 96 LGERA 268; BC9704825 . If the ratio decidendi is not readily discernible, then the inferior court is bound to apply the decision of a superior tribunal when the facts of the case under consideration "are not reasonably distinguishable from those which gave rise to the decision": Re Tyler; Ex parte Foley (1994) 181 CLR 18 at 37; 121 ALR 153; BC9404630 per McHugh J. The Local Court is not bound by decisions of the District Court since both are inferior courts operating within the overall hierarchy of courts: Valentine v Eid (1992) 27 NSWLR 615; 15 MVR 541 .

As an inferior “court of record” created by statute, the Local Court essentially has no powers, jurisdictions or authorities other than those authorised by statute: Irving v Askew (1870) LR 5 QB 208; R v Hackett; Ex parte Cline (1882) 8 VLR (L) 129 ; Levoune v Bacoulis 1935 AR (NSW) 126; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales (1986) 5 NSWLR 465 at 476 per McHugh JA.

"The chief distinctions between superior and inferior courts are found in connection with jurisdiction. Prima facie, no matter is deemed to be beyond the jurisdiction of a superior court unless it is expressly shown to be so, while nothing is within the jurisdiction of an inferior court unless it is expressly shown on the face of the proceedings that the particular matter is within the cognisance of the particular court": Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, vol 10, at [309]. Thus the Local Court, as an inferior court founded by statute, finds authority for its acts in legislation or by implications properly drawn therefrom: Ex parte Currie; Re Dempsey [1970] 1 NSWR 617; (1969) 70 SR (NSW) 443 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales, above; Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 . Beyond its legislative powers, the Local Court does possess:

[j]urisdiction arising by implication upon the principle that a grant of power carries with it everything necessary for its exercise (ubi aliquid conceditur, conceditur et id sine quo res ipsa esse non potest). Those implied powers may in many instances serve a function similar to that served by the inherent powers exercised by a superior court but they are derived from a different source and are limited in their extent. The distinction between inherent jurisdiction and jurisdiction by implication is not always made explicit, but it is … fundamental. (Grassby v R (1989) 168 CLR 1; 87 ALR 618 at 636–7; BC8902704 per Dawson J)

However, in Hoskins v Van Den-Braak (1998) 43 NSWLR 290; BC9801033 , the Court of Appeal was considering an application to set aside a judgment on the grounds of irregularity: the judgment debtor had not been served with the cross-claim which formed the basis of the judgment entered against him. The applicant was in breach of s 75A(3) of the now repealed Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 in that he had taken certain “fresh steps” (applying to pay by instalments) after becoming aware of the irregularity. The court held that regardless of anything the Act or Rules said, such persons had an unconditional right to have any judgment or order recorded against them contrary to the principles of natural justice set aside ex debito justitiae. Mason P adopted the words of Rich J in Cameron v Cole (1944) 68 CLR 571 at 589; [1944] ALR 130 at 136; BC4400034 :

[i]t is a fundamental principle of natural justice, applicable to all courts whether superior or inferior, that a person against whom a claim or charge is made must be given a reasonable opportunity of appearing and presenting his case … and a court which finds that it has been led to purport to determine a matter in which there has been a failure to observe the principle has inherent jurisdiction to set its determination aside.

The implied power (of statutory courts) to prevent abuse of process is similar to, if not identical with, inherent power: Director of Public Prosecutions (NSW) v Shirvaniam (1998) 44 NSWLR 129; (1998) 102 A Crim R 180; BC9802628 . As to the implied (as distinct from inherent) powers enjoyed by a statutory court such as the Land and Environment Court, see Logwon Pty Ltd v Warringah Shire Council (1993) 33 NSWLR 13; 82 LGERA 158; BC9303911 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7.15] Practical consequences of the principle that the Local Court must act within the express terms of its charter or those necessarily implied

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 7.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 36.2, 36.3.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 39.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 72.

heading.title: Practical consequences of the principle that the Local Court must act within the express terms of its charter or those necessarily implied

p.text: A practical consequences of the principle that the Local Court must act within the terms of its charter or those necessarily implied is that the requirements of UCPR rr 36.2 and 36.3 (relating to reserved judgments and the delivery of written reasons for judgment) must be strictly complied with, so that the parties are on notice that they may attend and hear the judgment or decision given by the magistrate or read by the registrar: Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 . See also [36.2.5] and [36.2.10] . However, the duty to provide reasons does not require the judicial officer, at trial, to spell out in minute detail every step in the reasoning process or refer to every single piece of evidence, or (per Mahoney JA in Housing Commission of NSW v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378 at 386; (1983) 53 LGRA 325 ) make express findings in respect of every piece of fact: “It will be sufficient if the inference as to what is found is appropriately clear”. It is sufficient if the reasons adequately reveal the basis of the decision, expressing the specific findings that are critical to the determination of the proceedings: Stoker v Adecco Gemvale Constructions Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 449; BC200408635 at [41] . It is essential to expose the reasoning on a point critical to the contest between the parties: Pollard v RRR Corp Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 110; BC200903917 at [58] . Appropriate allowance should be made for the pressures under which magistrates are placed by the volume of cases coming before them: Director of Public Prosecutions (NSW) v Illawarra Cashmart Pty Ltd (2006) 67 NSWLR 402 at 408; [2006] NSWSC 343; BC200602646 at [15]–[18] ; however, the minimum requirements enunciated in Stoker v Adecco Gemvale Constructions Pty Ltd, above, need to be observed: Munro v ACP [2012] NSWSC 100; BC201203462 per RA Hulme J at [21], [22]. Reasons may be inadequate, but the correct result may yet be achieved, because in the context of an appeal under s 39 of the Local Court Act 2007, “appeals are against judgments and not against reasons as such”, so that the judgment may be correct despite error being demonstrated: Motel Federation of Australia Ltd t/as Best Western Australia v Lenarbo Pty Ltd t/as Golden Age Motor Inn [2010] NSWSC 806; BC201005249 per Davies J; Moloney v Collins [2011] NSWSC 628; BC201104699 at [74] per Johnson J. It is not satisfactory, that an appeal court is left to undertake an analysis of exchanges between the bench and counsel during submissions in an attempt to ascertain a magistrate's reasons for determination: Director of Public Prosecutions (NSW) v Illawarra Cashmart Pty Ltd (2006) 67 NSWLR 402; [2006] NSWSC 343; BC200602646 at [15]–[19] ; Director of Public Prosecutions (NSW) v Zhang (2007) 48 MVR 78; [2007] NSWSC 308; BC200702344 at [60] . These are both decisions of Johnson J in the criminal jurisdiction, but are no less relevant in civil proceedings. Where there is nothing in the judicial officer's reasons but an assertion based on undifferentiated evidence, the judicial function has not been discharged: Soulemezis v Dudley (Holdings) Pty Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 247 , per Kirby P at 259. As stated by Mahoney JA in Soulemezis, at 280:

The extent of the duty to give reasons is related “to the function to be served by the giving of reasons”. Thus more elaborate reasons are required where legislation gives a right of appeal against a decision than where no appeal lies.

This was approved by Doyle CJ in R v Keyte (2000) 78 SASR 68; 211 LSJS 200; [2000] SASC 382; BC200006977 . Similarly, findings of fact in the reasons based on credibility may be set aside on appeal where incontrovertible facts or uncontested testimony demonstrate that the trial judicial officer's conclusions are erroneous or where it is concluded that the decision at the trial was glaringly improbable or contrary to compelling inferences in the case: Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 ; CSR Ltd v Della Maddalena (2006) 224 ALR 1; [2006] HCA 1; BC200600188 . It is also inappropriate for a judicial officer to take an adverse view of the credit of a party without referring in his judgment to apparently strongly corroborative evidence, or giving reasons for reaching his view despite such evidence; or, conversely, taking a favourable view of the credit of a party without referring in his judgment to apparently strongly demonstrably false evidence in other areas or giving reasons for reaching his view despite such evidence: Divall v Mifsud [2005] NSWCA 447; BC200510783 ; Brown v Harding [2008] NSWCA 51; BC200802107 ; Malco Engineering Pty Ltd v Ferreira (1994) 10 NSWCCR 117; BC9402316 per Handley JA at [117] (respondent gave false evidence regarding his wife’s dependency and the extent of his disability, but trial judge accepted his evidence regarding his injuries; trial judge found to have erred); Nominal Defendant v McLennan [2012] NSWCA 148; BC201203253 (trial judge impermissibly quarantined his findings that the respondent had lied on many occasions over a 12 year period, including around the period of the accident, from his conclusion that the respondent’s earlier and consistent accounts of the incident were credible and supportive of the fact that he was struck by a vehicle; trial judge failed to use or palpably misused his advantage as a trial judge; Beazley JA dissenting). See also [36.2.10], para (d).

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7.15.10] Court suppression and non-publication orders

p.text: The power to make such orders is now governed by the Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 which commenced on 1 July 2011. If made, such an order will prohibit or restrict the publication or other disclosure of information that reveals the identity of or otherwise concerns any party to or witness in proceedings before the court or any person who is related to or otherwise associated with any party to or witness in proceedings before the court; or information that comprises evidence, or information about evidence, given in proceedings before the court: s 7. Such an order may be made on the court’s own initiative, or on the application of a party to the proceedings, or any other person considered by the court to have a sufficient interest in making the order: s 9(1). The grounds for making the order include preventing prejudice to the proper administration of justice, national or international security, protecting the safety of any person, to avoid causing undue distress or embarrassment to a party to or witness in criminal proceedings involving an offence of a sexual nature, whether it is otherwise necessary in the public interest for the order to be made and that public interest significantly outweighs the public interest in open justice: s 8(1). Section 72 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 has been repealed. The Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 is reproduced at [301,000]–[301,375]

Relevant authorities under the law as it stood before the Act came into force, which may be useful in interpreting its provisions, follow. The basic principle was then said to be one of open courts and open justice, and it is the interest of justice which is the relevant consideration, not the interests of a private individual. This principle was reaffirmed in a number of decisions: John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd v Local Court of New South Wales (1991) 26 NSWLR 131; 26 ALD 471 ; John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 50 ACSR 380; (2004) 61 NSWLR 344; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 (District Court made order for non-publication of a verdict; order made without power; such a power was the subject of exercise only by implication and by necessity from the conferral of a criminal jurisdiction; no power to make a non-publication order directed only to persons unrelated to the proceedings); John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Ryde Local Court (2005) 62 NSWLR 512; 220 ALR 248; [2005] NSWCA 101; BC200501968 ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (NSW) (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 ; R v Kwok (2005) 64 NSWLR 335; 158 A Crim R 160; [2005] NSWCCA 245; BC200511149 ; O’Shane v Burwood Local Court [2007] NSWSC 1300; BC200709920 (no power to make a non-publication order in application for a personal violence order; not necessary to do so in order to secure the proper administration of justice). Analogous principles apply in the Local Court, another inferior court. Examples of cases where the courts have been held entitled to make such orders include instances of blackmail, extortion and for the protection of witnesses. Under the new legislation s 6 states, “in deciding whether to make a suppression order or non-publication order, a court must take into account that a primary objective of the administration of justice is to safeguard the public interest in open justice”, and the final requirement in s 8 is that it is in the public interest for the order to be made and that public interest significantly outweighs the public interest in open justice: s 8(1).

Under the law as it previously stood, the onus lay on the party seeking to exclude publicity of the identity of witnesses in court to justify the need for such exclusion: (Scott v Scott [1913] AC 417 ). That principle must now be read subject to the requirements of ss 6 and 8 of the new Act. Relevant considerations to consider are whether the order sought is designed to protect the witness as a witness before the court; whether the order is designed to prevent the publication of evidence that would as a result destroy the object of the proceedings and whether the order is sought in pursuance of a requirement of public policy or of a statutory provision: John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales, above at 476 per McHugh JA. Local Courts previously had jurisdiction to make orders that the alleged victims in an extortion case be referred to by pseudonyms, since they had implied incidental power to make orders necessary to secure "the proper administration of justice in the proceedings": John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd v Local Courts of New South Wales (1991) 26 NSWLR 131; 26 ALD 471; 59 A Crim R 68 . It has been held that an inferior court had no jurisdiction to make an order designed to restrain a threatened contempt of the court, for example by making an order prohibiting a television channel from telecasting certain material relating to a then current criminal trial: United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 .

It was previously held that neither superior nor inferior courts had the power to make an order protecting a stranger from the detrimental consequences of publishing any evidence given before it (John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales, above, per McHugh JA) nor to order that the use of pseudonyms in relation to certain classes of crown witnesses (such as the victims of blackmail) should be extended to accused persons who are involved in the prosecution only because it is their act which has constituted the foundation of the crime charged and who seek to raise the embarrassing issue in order to escape what would otherwise be the likely consequences of their own act: R v White-Cotterell (NSWSC, Hunt CJ, No 70020/92, 29 October 1992, unreported, BC9201521). Those decisions must now be considered subject to the requirements in the new Act.

Magistrates called upon to deal with an application to suppress the name of a party or witness must attach great importance to the primary rule that justice must ordinarily be administered in open court: Connors v Stent (NSWSC, Brownie J, 22 April 1987, unreported). As to cases where courts have made non-publication orders to ensure the anonymity of plaintiffs who may suffer embarrassment because of medically acquired HIV infection or AIDS, see E v Australian Red Cross Society (1991) 27 FCR 310; 99 ALR 601 at 604 ; TK v Australian Red Cross Society [1989] 1 WAR 335; TC v Australian Red Cross Society (VSC, Young CJ, No 2927, 4 August 1989, unreported). These cases were followed by Cole J in DM v TD (NSWSC, Cole J, 4 February 1994, unreported, BC9402267), for the sake of judicial comity although he did not agree with the principle himself, being not persuaded that the proper administration of justice required the non-disclosure of the plaintiff's name.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7.20] What constitutes “the record” for the purposes of certiorari

heading.title: What constitutes “the record” for the purposes of certiorari

p.text: Where there is an error of law on the face of the record of an inferior court such as the Local Court, certiorari is available for the purpose of having the error quashed after the record has been called up by the Supreme Court: Tehrani v Rostrow [1972] 1 QB 182 at 187; [1971] 3 All ER 790 per Denning MR.

In the case of certiorari on the basis of jurisdictional error on the face of the record, the record will generally refer to no more than the documentation which initiates the proceedings, the pleadings (if any) and the adjudication. It will not ordinarily include the reasons for the decision and the transcript of the proceedings. However, these may be included if the inferior court chooses to incorporate them in an integral part of its order and "the record". A mere incidental reference or introductory remark such as "accordingly" or "for the reasons given" will not of itself have the effect of incorporating the whole or any part of the reasons for decision in either the formal order or the "record": Craig v South Australia (1995) 184 CLR 163; 131 ALR 595; [1995] HCA 58; BC9506437 . As to the pleadings of an inferior court such as the District and Local Court forming part of the record, see also Seymour v Sherian (NSWCA, Moffit P, Mahoney and Priestley JJA, 417/1983, 15 November 1983, unreported).

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 7.25] Record of proceedings must be kept

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 7.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 51(2).
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 35(6).

heading.title: Record of proceedings must be kept

p.text: As to the magistrate's duty to keep a proper record of the proceedings, see Pinkstone v Goldrick [1979] 1 NSWLR 279 ; Sherring v Goldrick [1979] 1 NSWLR 285 . These cases are of historical interest only as it is now the almost invariable practice for all proceedings in the NSW Local Court to be recorded, by sound or other means. Proceedings referred for arbitration under the CPA are not required to be recorded (CPA s 51(2) ), nor are proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Court: LCA 2007 s 35(6) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 8] s 8 Single Magistrate to constitute the Court (cf LCA 1982, section 8)

leg:heading.title: Single Magistrate to constitute the Court (cf LCA 1982, section 8 )

p.text: Except as may be otherwise provided by or under this Act or any other Act or law, all proceedings in the Court, including all business arising out of any such proceedings, are to be heard and determined by a Magistrate, who is to constitute the Court.
The Court has:
a civil jurisdiction consisting of the jurisdiction conferred on it by Part 3 , and
a special jurisdiction consisting of the jurisdiction conferred on it by or under any other Act or law with respect to proceedings to which Part 4 applies, and
a criminal jurisdiction consisting of the jurisdiction conferred on it by or under any other Act or law with respect to criminal proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 10] s 10 Divisions of the Court (cf LCA 1982, section 7A)

leg:heading.title: Divisions of the Court (cf LCA 1982, section 7A )

p.text: For the purpose of exercising its civil jurisdiction, the Court is divided into:
the General Division, and
the Small Claims Division.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 11] s 11 State-wide jurisdiction (cf LCA 1982, section 17)

p.text: The Court, wherever sitting, has jurisdiction throughout the whole of New South Wales.
